Posts.Content: willy2351 wrote: Hi everyone.  I finished 8 rounds of chemo in March, had a bi-lateral mastectomy in April and finished 33 rounds of radiation 4 weeks ago.  The two tumors and cancerous lymph nodes were in the left breast.  The mastectomy drains were removed a week after surgery.  A week later I had a lot of fluid build-up so my surgeon suggested aspirating the breast.  For 3 consecutive weeks he aspirated the fluid build-up and then radiation began at which time I said no more aspirations! Now I have a fluid filled breast (my fluib ) on the left side.  Pre-mastectomy I was a 36B.  My left breast is now an A cup.  (And much more pert than my 60 year old B cup) My medical onc and radiation onc say there's nothing that can be done and this is the way my breast will be from now on, but I wonder... I have neuropathy in both hands and arms but I'm pretty sure I don't have lymphodema. Has anyone else had this experience?  The oncs say it's lymph fluid.  I just wonder about lymph fluid  hanging around.... Any insights or suggestions or voices of experience (jokes are fine, too)  would be appreciated. Thank you! Debbi DX TNBC 9/09; age 59 Stage III, Grade 3 Two tumors; pos node(s?) B-40 trial -4 rounds Taxotere/Avastin;2 rounds A/C with Avastin;2 rounds A/C. Bi-lat mast 4/2010; 4/7 pos nodes 33 rads,10 Avastin Dx 8/27/2009, IDC, 2cm, Stage IIB, Grade 3, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Does anyone have a "fluib"? willy2351 worldwatcher
